question.title: MyIntListImpl is not abstract and does not override abstract method getItem() in IMyDummyList
question.body:
I don't understand why my class that extends an abstract class (which implements an interface) does not override the interface's single method. I get this error when I try to compile:

MyIntListImpl is not abstract and does not override abstract method getItem() in IMyDummyList

In some cases, IDEA shows messages of the form "method blabla clashes with 'getItems()' in 'IMyDummyList'; incompatible return type".

My code:

interface IMyDummy {
  Object getItem();
}

interface IMyDummyList {
  List<IMyDummy> getItems();
}

abstract class AbsItem<T extends JsonBase> implements IMyDummy {
  public abstract T getItem();
}

class JsonBase {
  public Object pupupidu() {
    return new Object();
  }
}

abstract class Abs<T extends JsonBase> implements IMyDummyList {
  public abstract List<? extends AbsItem<T>> getItems();
}

class MyDummyClass extends JsonBase {
}

class IMyDummyImpl extends AbsItem<MyDummyClass> {
  public MyDummyClass getItem() {
    return new MyDummyClass();
  }
  public String getKey() {
    return "test";
  }
}

abstract class AbsMyIntListImpl extends Abs<MyDummyClass> {
  public abstract List<IMyDummyImpl> getItems();
}

class MyIntListImpl extends AbsMyIntListImpl {
  private List<IMyDummyImpl> items;

  public List<IMyDummyImpl> getItems() {
    return this.items;
  }

  public static void main() {
    System.out.println("hello");
  }
}

I need MyIntListImpl to extend AbsMyIntListImpl. Other classes already extend MyIntListImpl.

answers.body:
You need to either define your interface as

interface IMyDummyList {
    List<? extends IMyDummy> getItems();
}

or define abstract method as

public abstract List<IMyDummy> getItems();

And this is because compiler treats List<? extends AbsItem<T>> and List<IMyDummy> as different types.

In other words List<IMyDummy tells that it needs to be colleciton of IMyDummy objects. However List<? extends IMyDummy> allows for implementations to have collection of objects of class inheriting from IMyDummy.

The problem is solved by adding a type variable to the IMyDummyList interface

public interface IMyDummyList<I extends IMyDummy> {
    List<I> getItems();
}

next

public abstract class Abs<T extends JsonBase, I extends IMyDummy> implements IMyDummyList<I> {    public abstract List<I> getItems();}


// you can do it even like this way:

public abstract class Abs<T extends JsonBase & IMyDummy> implements IMyDummyList<T> {    public abstract List<T> getItems();
}

// and last step was:

public abstract class AbsMyIntListImpl extends Abs<MyDummyClass, IMyDummyImpl> {
    public abstract List<IMyDummyImpl> getItems();
}

question_comments.body: i dont have idea. Why getItems() in Abs<AbsMyIntListImpl> clashes getItems() IMyDummyList? getItems in Abs<AbsMyIntListImpl> returns typed class.
'getItems()' in 'org.example.AbsMyIntListImpl' clashes with 'getItems()' in 'org.example.IMyDummyList'; incompatible return type. The problem has not been solved.

@user27630372, after you updated the method name in IMyDummyList, does the error message you quoted remain. I suspect that "Yep, fixed it" means not. In that case, does anything remain unanswered here?

@Progman, I'm pretty sure the OP's original "to inherit X from Y" was an awkward way of saying "Y to extend X", as indeed matches the code.  I take them to be saying that the existing inheritance hierarchy must not be altered, as my edit reflects.

@user27630372 Please edit your question to update the complete error message you get now. Also clarify the sentence "I exactly need to inherit AbsMyIntListImpl from MyIntListImpl", since in your code you wrote class MyIntListImpl extends AbsMyIntListImpl, which is the other way around. Which class should extend from the other class?
